titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0902, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Four gospels in Greek. Ammonian section and Eusebian canon numbers in the margins. Lectionary headings and incipits in the text. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 36.
The manuscript is commonly known as the Gamma Gospels because of the uncial form of the letter Gamma ( Γ ) found throughout the text.

minItem.minDesc: Evangelist, John, Portrait: John holds book, seated in high-backed chair before writing table.
minItem.note: The single miniature, thought to be a later addition, has been embellished with a small line drawing of a bird (eagle?), upper left.

headpieces.p: Headpieces (John) of foliate and abstract motifs in red and black (fols. 50v, 53r).

initials.p: Major initial for John (40 mm), geometric design of red, white, and black, set off from the text. Minor initials in red.

foliation.p: 1-94. Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil.

layout.p: 1 column, 23-25 lines (variants of 26-28 lines). Frame ruling with hard point.

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in dark brown ink (fading and flaking).
Punctuation includes high point, comma, and marks of interrogation and elision.
Methods of correcting text consist of erasure, and marginal additions marked with asterisks in red or the scribal sign γρ. Several interlinear corrections.

textDivisions.p: Titles in red. Lection indicators αρχε (beginning) and τελος (end).

condition.p: Leaves moderately cockled, several broken or torn. Water and mold damage.

binding.p: Covers lost. Quires stitched together with cord.

origin.p: The manuscript is dated to the 13th century, and is judged to have been written in either Greece or Asia Minor.

provenance.p: Medieval to early 20th century provenance unknown. Before 1934, the manuscript was in Caesarea, the present-day Kayseri, Turkey where it was purchased by an agent of the American numismatist Daniel Kellad (1893-1986).

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago in 1935 from Mr. Kellad with funds provided by Dr. James M. Stifler, John S. Miller, and the Friends of the Library.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

overview.p: Four gospels in Greek. Ammonian section and Eusebian canon numbers in the margins. Lectionary headings and incipits in the text. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 36.
The manuscript is commonly known as the Gamma Gospels because of the uncial form of the letter Gamma ( Γ ) found throughout the text.

msItem.summary: Matthew (begins at 27:23 with εφη, το 27:38 with ευωνυμων. Continues at 28:4 with εσεισθησαν and ends at 28:20 with παν[τα]).
Luke (begins at 7:47 with ολιγον). Subscription and stichoi (2,800).
Death of the holy apostle and evangelist John (η μεταστασις του αγιου αποστολου και ευαγγελιστου Ιωαννου).

msItem.note: In the text after 7:52, verse 8:12 was inserted before the pericope of the woman taken in adultery (7:53-8:11).

bibl.title: Die Schriften des Neuen Testaments in ihrer ältesten erreichbaren Textgestalt

bibl.author: Seymour de Ricci,
bibl.title: Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada
